se.softhouse.common.guavaextensions

Class Predicates2

  • java.lang.Object
    • se.softhouse.common.guavaextensions.Predicates2

  • @Immutable
public final class Predicates2
extends Object
    Additional implementations of the Predicate interface

    • Method Detail

      • alwaysFalse

        public static <T> Predicate<T> alwaysFalse()

      • alwaysTrue

      • and

        public static <T> Predicate<? super T> and(Predicate<? super T> first,
                                           Predicate<? super T> second)
        Works just like Predicate.and(Predicate) except that if first is alwaysTrue() second is returned directly (or vice versa). This has the potential to make Object.toString() look a bit nicer for the resulting Predicate.

      • in

        public static <T> Predicate<T> in(Collection<? extends T> target)
        Creates a Predicate which mandates that target contains the tested object
        Type Parameters:
        T - type of objects in target
        Parameters:
        target - the collection that contains the "ok" objects
        Returns:
        the newly created Predicate

      • listPredicate

        public static <E> Predicate<List<? extends E>> listPredicate(Predicate<E> elementLimiter)
        Returns a predicate that throws an IllegalArgumentException if any element in a list doesn't return true for elementLimiter.apply(Object). Useful for input validation where you already have a Predicate for the element type and want to check a list of such elements. Without listPredicate(Predicate) it would look something like: 
         
 List<Integer> numbers = Arrays.asList(1, -1, -2);
 Optional<Integer> invalidNumber = Iterables.tryFind(numbers, Predicates.not(ABOVE_ZERO));
 if(invalidNumber.isPresent())
   throw new IllegalArgumentException("'" + invalidNumber.get() + "' is not " + ABOVE_ZERO);
        With listPredicate(Predicate): 
         
 Predicates2.listPredicate(ABOVE_ZERO).apply(numbers);
        As this breaks the general contract of Predicate.test(Object) it should be considered useful for validating arguments only. The detail message only mentions the first element that didn't return true.
